II. 

THE SECTOR: PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

A. 

Sector Description and Performance 

2. 
By  most  measures  of  performance,  Viet  Nam  has  experienced  successful  economic 
growth  and  poverty  reduction  over  the  last  15  years  since  economic  reform  or  doi  moi  was 
introduced in 1986. During the 1990s, gross domestic product (GDP) grew at an average rate of 
about 7.5% per year, and in 2002 was an estimated 5.7%.1 Agriculture accounts for about 22% 
of  GDP.  Per  capita  GDP  almost  doubled  during  the  last  decade,  and  the  ratio  of  domestic 
savings  to  GDP  increased  by  2.5  times.  Capital  formation  also  almost  doubled  during  this 
period. The economic slowdown that started in 2000 and was accentuated after 11 September 
2001  has  dampened  GDP  growth  in  recent  years.  Foreign  direct  investment  has  slackened 
since  its  peak  in  the  mid-1990s,  largely  due  to  perceptions  that  the  cost  of  doing  business  in 
Viet  Nam  is  high  and  that  the  Government  is  not  willing  to  accelerate  economic  reforms. 
Nevertheless,  macroeconomic  indicators  such  as  inflation,  fiscal  deficits,  current  account 
deficits, and external debt are within manageable limits. 
 
3. 
The incidence of poverty had been cut in half, from about 70% in 1990 to 37% in 2000. 
Rural poverty was reduced from 66% in 1993 to 45% in 1998. There has also been significant 
improvement in social indicators, with almost universal primary education access, and reduced 
incidence  of  infant  mortality,  under-five  mortality,  child  malnutrition,  and  maternal  mortality. 
However, there are major challenges in reducing poverty further. The incidence of rural poverty 
is much higher, and about 90% of the total poor population reside in rural areas. Poor villages 
and communes lack basic infrastructure and health facilities. Poverty incidence is higher in the 
northern areas (60%) and among ethnic minorities (75%).  
 
4. 
Agricultural growth and rural poverty reduction have also been impressive over the last 
decade.  Growth  in  agricultural  production  averaged  4-5%  per  annum,  and  the  value  of 
agricultural output (80% in the form of crops and livestock, with the remainder from forestry and 
fisheries)  grew  4.2%  per  year  (Appendix  1).  Agricultural  growth  was  among  the  highest  in  the 
world  during  the  1990s,  comparable  with  that  in  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC).  This 
growth  was  mainly  due  to  market-oriented  reforms  that  recognized  the  farm  household  as  the 
key  unit  of  production,  liberalized  land-use  rights,  and  liberalized  decision  making  on  the 
purchase  of  inputs  and  sale  of  outputs.  The  ratio  of  cultivatable  land  per  person  is  very  low, 
suggesting  that  Viet  Nam  has  a  comparative  advantage  in  production  that  maximizes  value-
added  per  unit  of  land.  Agriculture  will  continue  to  grow  at  a  lower  rate  than  industry  and 
services; thus, acceleration of employment in rural services and industry is essential to minimize 
widening income disparities. Rice production (accounting for 60% of the cultivated area) grew at 
4.3%  during  the  1990s  due  to  increases  in  yield  and  cropping  intensity.  The  growth  in 
agricultural exports was also noteworthy. The value of agricultural exports grew at over 13% per 
year  during  this  period,  and  is  currently  about  $4.4  billion  per  year,  more  than  60%  of 
agricultural  GDP.  Rice,  coffee,  rubber,  cashews,  tea,  pepper,  and  seafood  are  the  major 
agricultural export items.

B. 

Issues and Opportunities 

1. 

Problem Analysis 

6. 
The  past  agricultural  strategy  was  largely  successful  in  generating  and  sustaining  self-
sufficiency in food, expanding exports, increasing rural employment, and reducing rural poverty. 
However,  the  strategy  is  no  longer  sufficient  to  ensure  future  sustained  agricultural  growth  in 
productivity and poverty reduction, because of declining (i) returns to labor, (ii) rice demand and 
exports due to low quality, and (iii) returns to irrigation infrastructure where rice is the dominant 
output. Also, growth in agriculture value-added declined from a high of 5.2% in 1999 to 2.3% in 
2001, and an estimated 2.1% in 2002.4  In contrast, industry and services experienced higher 
and  increasing  growth  rates  in  this  period.  Viet  Nam  has  been  a  successful  exporter  of  low-
quality  rice  (e.g.,  high  quantity  of  broken  rice  to  Africa,  Indonesia,  and  Philippines),  coffee, 
rubber, cashew, tea, and black pepper. Viet Nam has not been successful in producing higher 
quality and higher priced agricultural commodities for export. As a result, while export volumes 
of  these  major  commodities  have  continued  to  rise  since  2000,  export  values  and  revenues 
have fallen due to low prices for rice, coffee, and tea in international markets.5 This situation is 
expected to continue in the medium term. Agricultural value-added per hectare (ha) is relatively 
high in Viet Nam by international standards (about $1,000/ha). However, the small  size of the 
average farm (0.14 ha/capita) means that value-added per person is low ($140/person). A new 
strategy  based  on  crop  diversification  and  growth  in  high-quality  and  high-value  products  is 
needed. It will require shifting the focus from a primary commodity to a finished or intermediate 
product, and from production volume to quality value addition. 
 
7. 
The  core  sector  problems  are  low  productivity  and  profitability,  lack  of  production 
diversity, low quality, and low competitiveness of the agricultural system. The causes of these 
problems  include  (i)  low  agricultural  diversification;  (ii)  weak  integration  with  postharvest 
systems  and  response  to  market  quality  requirements;  (iii)  poor  management  of  natural 
resources; (iv) low private sector investment in agricultural processing, trade, and input supply; 
and (v) weak stakeholder participation in efforts to improve extension and production. The major 
factors  contributing

8. 
 Agricultural research in Viet Nam is characterized by a fragmentation of efforts. About 
37  research  institutes  with  small  budgets  exist.  Their  concentration  in  the  Red  River  and 
Mekong  Deltas,  with  insufficient  representation  in  other  agroecological  zones,  limits  the 
relevance  of  research  results.  Viet  Nam  spends  only  about  0.3%  of  agricultural  GDP  on 
research,  compared  with  0.6%  in  the  PRC  and  1.4%  in  Thailand.  Other  problems  are  poor 
coordination  among  research  institutions,  weak  linkages  with  extension,  a  shortage  of

infrastructure,  and  insufficient  involvement  of  stakeholders.  On  the  other  hand,  irrigation 
absorbs the largest share (50%) of the state budget to agriculture; most (90%) of this is used for 
capital expenditures. As a result, operation and maintenance are neglected. 
 
9. 
The national extension system created recently in 1993 is operational in only 50% of the 
communes  (collection  of  villages).  The  farmer-agent  ratio  is  estimated  at  1,250:1.  Other 
constraints  include  a  top-down  approach  in  dealing  with  farmers,  insufficient  knowledge  and 
skills  in  effective  communication,  poor  technological  recommendations,  lack  of  funding  for 
effective operations (despite the fact that provincial governments provide about 50% of annual 
budgets), and ineffective use of mass media and information technology. Public expenditure on 
agricultural extension in 2002 was  only D441 billion ($29 million) or 0.4% of agricultural GDP. 
This is very low compared with that in neighboring PRC, Thailand, and Malaysia. 
 
10. 
Improved seed is produced by a variety of organizations, including universities, research 
institutes,  public  seed  agencies,  and  private  seed  companies.  Because  of  limited  funding  for 
breeding and research operations, research institutes supplement their budgets with the sale of 
seed directly to both seed companies and farmers. Quality control is insufficient and limited to 
testing  by  the  National  Center  for  Variety  Evaluation  and  Seed  Certification.  The  Danish 
International  Development  Agency  (Danida)  is  currently  funding  a  seed  project  as  part  of  the 
Agriculture  Sector  Program  Support,  with  a  focus  on  seed  certification,  quality  control  and 
regulation,  seed  research  and  pathology,  and  seed  production  and  processing.  Efforts  are 
focused on rice and maize seeds, the two most important food crops, and institutional support at 
national,  provincial,  and  on-farm  levels.  De  facto  restrictions  prevent  trade  in  seed  between

Sustainable  growth  of  the  agriculture  sector  is  a  prerequisite  for  economic  growth  and 
poverty  reduction  in  Viet  Nam.  Despite  progress  in  agricultural  production  and  export  growth 
and  in  liberalizing  commodity,  land,  and  credit  markets  in  recent  years,  rural  poverty  remains 
high  and  private  sector  investment  remains  small.  Growth  in  the  past  was  the  result  of  (i) 
reliance on higher input use (labor, capital, and water); (ii) policy reforms in land, markets, and 
trade;  and  (iii)  high  public  investment,  mainly  in  the  form  of  irrigation  and  roads.  The  annual

(14%), land (11%), basic intermediate inputs such as fertilizer (51%), tractors (14%), and water 
pumps for irrigation (5%), with total factor productivity through other technology accounting for 
only 4%.9 Thus, the sector strategy of the 1990s will not be able to sustain growth in the future 
because (i) the potential for expanding the rural labor force and land under cultivation is limited; 
(ii)  new  investment  in  irrigation  exhibits  decreasing  marginal  returns  as  the  stock  of  irrigation 
capital is already very high and requires increased operation, maintenance, and management in 
addition  to  new  expansion  for  irrigation,  water  supply,  and  flood  control;  and  (iii)  rice  export 
revenue  is  declining  due  to  poor  quality  and  dependence  on  low-end  markets.  Viet  Nam  is 
already  experiencing  difficulties  in  competition  for  markets  in  rice,  coffee,  and  other 
unprocessed commodities.

28.

greater participation of rural households in sector development efforts. ASDP includes specific 
reform  measures  to  (i)  strengthen  support  services  in  science  and  technology  (research  and

3. 

Financing Plan 

45. 
It is proposed that ADB provide a loan of $60 million equivalent denominated in Special 
Drawing Rights from its Special Funds resources for ASDP, with a term of 24 years, including a 
grace period of 8 years, and an interest charge of 1% per annum during the grace period and 
1.5% per annum thereafter. The loan will finance the policy reforms in three tranches over a 3-
year period, from January 2003 to December 2005. This amount was determined through ADB’s 
continued  dialogue  with  the  Government  and  the  size  of  the  short-term  adjustment  costs  of 
implementing the Program. Use of low-cost funds from ADB’s Special Funds resources is justified 
in support of policy reforms that address complex and long-standing issues and socially significant 
measures to (i) enhance benefits to small farmers; (ii) free government resources currently used 
in  subsidies;  and  (iii)  improve  the  terms  of  trade  for  agriculture  on  which  the  livelihood  of  the 
majority  of  the  households,  especially  the  poor,  depend.  In  addition,  the  adjustment  costs  to 
implement the Program are substantial. 
 
46. 
An  estimated  net  adjustment  cost  of  about  $90  million  is  required  to  catalyze  the 
changes to enhance productivity and profitability in the agriculture sector through the proposed 
reform  measures.  Reforming  the  research  and  extension  institutions  will  involve  restructuring 
the research organization and expanding the commune-level extension services. The services 
must  be  realigned  to  support  the  needs  of  farmers  at  the  subsistence  level  and  at  different 
levels of commercialization through participatory processes, and to improve coverage within the 
major  agroecological  zones.  This  will  involve,  initially,  increased  recurrent  expenditure  for 
research and extension to cover operating expenses (training and facilities improvements are to 
be covered under a subsequent investment phase). The loan will help the Government to adjust 
its recurrent budget to meet these incremental expenses. After the loan period, the Government 
will be fully responsible for maintaining the research and extension recurrent budget at its new 
level.  The  adjustment  costs  include  (i)  $42  million  for  increasing  the  Government’s  budgetary 
support  for  restructuring  and  modernizing  the  research  and  extension  systems,  and  (ii)  $49 
million for Government’s contributions to improve the asset quality of VBARD to resolve debts 
on nonperforming loans. These costs represent less than 2% of the annual capital budget of the 
national  and  local  governments  for  agriculture  by  during  2003–2007,  and  1%  of  the  average 
annual budget for all state-owned commercial banks during 2003–2007.

IV. 

PROGRAM BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 

A. 

Benefits 

74. 
Given  the  limited  growth  prospects  from  further  increased  use  of  physical  factors  and 
basic intermediate inputs, growth in productivity through access to and application of improved 
technology, information, and capital for private sector SMEs is key to maintaining growth in Viet 
Nam’s  agriculture  sector.  Consequently,  the  strengthening  of  agricultural  research  and 
extension  through  policy  and  institutional  reforms  is  expected  to  contribute  significantly  to 
sustaining sector growth targets over the next 10 years. Due to the exogenous macroeconomic 
and microeconomic influences on Viet Nam’s agriculture sector (e.g., time required for market 
and  land  reforms  to  take  full  effect,  and  sectorwide  effects  of  world  commodity  prices  and 
markets)  and  the  indirect  impacts  from  institutional  reforms  in  science  and  technology,  future 

 

 
 
 

  

21

contributions  to  agricultural  growth  from  the  Program  cannot  be  forecast  quantitatively. 
Nevertheless,  the  future  and  critical  roles  of  access  to  and  application  of  technology  and 
information  in  productivity  and  quality  improvements,  and  value  addition  by  farmers  and  agro-
industry  enterprises  in  Viet  Nam  are  demonstrated  in  program  preparation  studies.20  The 
impressive sector growth over the past decade was largely achieved through increased use of 
labor,  land,  basic  intermediate  inputs  (e.g.,  fertilizer),  irrigation,  and  machinery,  with  other 
technology accounting for only 4% of growth. With limited options for further increasing the use 
of  these  inputs,  future  growth  will  depend  on  growth  in  total  factor  productivity,  diversification, 
and quality and technology improvements. By more effectively identifying, testing, adapting, and 
disseminating  new  and  appropriate  technologies  and  having  them  adopted  by  farmers  and 
enterprises, the Program will significantly contribute to the Government’s annual growth targets 
of  4.5%  for  the  sector.  The  sector  growth  rate  required  to  equate  to  the  minimum  targeted 
incremental annual recurrent expenditure on research and extension of $5.5 million is less than 
0.01% per annum (i.e., the break-even growth rate), a small fraction of the targeted 4.5% sector 
growth rate. Similarly, total estimated adjustment costs from institutional reforms were less than 
1.3% of the sector GDP in 2000. 
 
75. 
Benefits to farmers and enterprises are likely to be realized through increased access to 
and  application  of  improved  technology.  These  benefits  include  (i)  increased  productivity  of 
existing  areas  under  production;  (ii)  increased value  through  improved  quality  of commodities; 
(iii) lower risk and avoidance of production loss; (iv) incremental production and processing; (v) 
increased net farm incomes and enterprise gross profits; and (vi) increased employment of rural 
people, including the poor. These increases are attributed to (i) acquisition and development of 
technologies  by  the  research  institutes;  (ii)  more  effective  dissemination  to  farmers  by 
agricultural extension agents, input suppliers, and traders; and (iii) farmers’ improved capacity to 
respond  to  markets  due  to  access  to  better  market  information  and  understanding  of  market 
opportunities. The full benefits of a rationalized and cost-effective research system that is more 
oriented  to  market  trends  and  farmer  needs,  and  an  expanded  and  participatory  extension 
system  are  likely  to  be  realized  in  the  medium  term.  However,  acquisition  and  transfer  of 
existing  proven  technologies  could  result  in  early  benefits.  Expanded  and  better  targeted 
services  resulting  from  the  reforms  will  benefit  subsistence,  semicommercial,  and  commercial 
farmers  in  irrigated,  rain-fed,  and  mountainous  areas.  In  addition,  expanded  support  services, 
while  requiring  additional  overall  fiscal  resources,  will  be  more  cost-effective  due  to  service 
rationalization  (e.g.,  reducing  the  number  of  research  institutes),  will  reduce  overheads  and 
duplication  of  services  and  expenditure  reallocation  (e.g.,  from  national  research  institutes  to 
regional and commodity- or disciplinary-specific institutes).  
 
76. 
The  provision  of  increased  funding  to  research,  extension,  market  information  systems, 
and  capital  for  value-adding  agro-industry  SMEs  will  facilitate  accelerated  investment  in  agro-
industry  and  the  adoption  of  new  technologies  crucial  to  their  success  in  a  competitive 
environment. Policy makers in Viet Nam see the rapid expansion of SMEs in the rural sector as an 
effective and largely neglected mechanism to increase employment and expand growth through

77.

Past Performance 

 
1. 
Agriculture plays a dominant role in the economy of Viet Nam, as it accounts for about 
30% of gross domestic product (GDP), 70% of employment, and 50% of export value. Although 
these shares will decline over the coming years as they have done slowly over the past decade, 
the  agriculture  sector  will  remain  at  the  core  of  the  country’s  economy  in  the  next  decade. 
Further,  since  poverty  is  mainly  a  rural  problem,  attacking  poverty  and  promoting  economic 
growth and national development will be critical challenges for agriculture. At the same time, a 
major  challenge  is  stimulating  growth  in  investment  and  off-farm  employment  through  private 
sector industries and other rural enterprises. 
 
A. 
 
2. 
The  past  performance  of  the  agriculture  sector  over  the  last  15  years  since  the 
introduction  of  doi  moi  (economic  reform)  in  1986  has  been  impressive.  Growth  in  agriculture 
averaged  4.3%  of  GDP  during  1980-1990,  and  increased  to  4.9%  of  GDP  during  1990–1999. 
This  growth  was  higher  than  that  in  India,  Indonesia,  Philippines,  and  Thailand,  and  was 
comparable  with  agricultural  growth  in  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC).  The  value  of 
agricultural  exports  rose  from  $1.1  billion  in  1990  to  $4.3  billion  in  1998.  The  sources  of 
agricultural growth were large increases in yields and production of rice, maize, industrial crops, 
fruits,  vegetables,  livestock,  and  seafood.  These  gains  were  attributed  to  policy  reforms  in 
markets,  land  and  trade,  widespread  use  of  improved  seeds  (including  hybrid  seed)  and 
livestock breeds, heavy application of fertilizers and pesticides, and large-scale investments in 
irrigation and road infrastructure. The Mekong River Delta and Red River Delta are the two main 
areas  that  experienced  rapid  agricultural  growth  and  improvement  in  farm  incomes  since  they 
are well served by irrigation and road infrastructure, banking services, and agricultural support 
services.  Other  areas,  particularly  the  northern  uplands,  the  interior  of  the  north  central  coast, 
and  northern  part  of  the  central  highlands,  experienced  much  slower  growth,  and  therefore 
suffer from a high level of poverty.

Seed Subsidies 

 
17. 
There  are  three  types  of  subsidy  on  hybrid  seeds:  (i)  a  subsidy  from  the  provincial 
governments  for  the  commercial  production  of  hybrid  rice  and  maize  seeds  in  four  provinces; 
(ii) a subsidy from the national Government, implemented through DAFE, for a pilot program in 
10 provinces to encourage farmers to grow and sell hybrid rice seeds to seed companies; and 
(iii)  a  poverty  reduction  program  administered  by  the  provincial  governments  to  provide 
subsidized hybrid rice seeds to poor and subsistence farmers in 18 mountainous provinces. The 
total amount spent on these subsidies in 2002 was $4.5 million equivalent: (i) $1.3 million for the 
provincial commercial production program, (ii) $0.5 million for the national pilot program, and (iii) 
$2.7 million for the provincial poverty reduction program. 
 
18. 
Viet  Nam  currently  produces  over  50%  of  its  hybrid  maize  seed  requirements 
domestically, so there is agreement within the Government that subsidies are no longer needed 
to  promote  its  commercial  production.  The  rationale  for  the  subsidies  on  the  commercial 
production  of  hybrid  rice  seeds  is  (i)  import  substitution  to  reduce  dependence  on  imported 
Chinese  rice  hybrid  seeds,  and  (ii)  price  stabilization  to  counter  occasional  high  prices  in  the 
PRC. Viet Nam currently plants about 17,000 tons of hybrid rice seed yearly, but produces only 
2,500–3,000 tons of hybrid seed domestically. The balance is imported from the PRC, usually 
the  male  and  female  lines  of  relatively  low-yielding  hybrids  from  private  seed  companies. 
Commercial seed companies in Viet Nam then cross these lines and the resulting hybrid seed is 
sold in domestic markets. The current price of imported hybrid rice seed is about $1,300 per ton 
and the 2002 import bill was about $22 million. The current price of hybrid seed grown in Viet 
Nam is about 20% less than the import price. The Government's objective is to produce about 
50%  of  total  domestic  demand  by  2005  (about  10,000  tons).  In  addition  to  promoting 
commercial  production  of  hybrid  rice  seed,  for  which  subsidies  will  end  in  2003,  MARD  has 
been financing a pilot extension program whereby farmers are provided free hybrid seeds, seed 
treatments,  and  training.  Seed  companies  choose  these  farmers,  and  the  national  extension 
service  gives  the  farmer  inputs  and  training  for  2–3  years  to  grow  seeds  for  sale  to  seed 
companies.  This  program  is  being  promoted  in  10  provinces  where  yields  are  highest.  The

The  major  rationale  for  promoting  hybrid  rice  to  poor  and  subsistence  farmers  is  that

subsidy for a poor farmer is spread over three crop seasons (the average is two rice crops per 
year) and comprises 100% of the price for the first rice crop, 50% for the second crop, 30% for 
the third crop, and 0% for the fourth crop onward. Poor farmers are usually able to sustain rice 
production after the termination of the subsidy since the quantity of hybrid rice seed required is 
so small: an average of 2 kilograms of rice seed, costing about $2 (equivalent to the price of two 
chickens). This poverty reduction program is financed entirely from the provincial budgets in 16 
northern provinces and 2 central provinces. 
 

6. 

Rural Finance 

 
20. 
Even though the three major rural financial institutions in Viet Nam, namely, the Vietnam 
Bank for Agriculture and Rural Development (VBARD), the Viet Nam Bank for the Poor (VBP), 
and  the  People’s  Credit  Funds  (PCF),  have  made  considerable  progress  in  outstanding  loans 
growth, the  needs of rural households for credit are still largely unmet. The country’s financial 
system  consists  of  the  formal,  semiformal,  and  informal  sectors.  The  formal  sector  reaches 
about  one  third  of  rural  households  with  a  small  average  loan  size  (about  $300)  and  a  short 
repayment  period  (less  than  1  year).  The  remaining  rural  households  obtain  their  credit  from 
semiformal and informal sources. Less than one half of the larger and commercial farmers are 
able  to  obtain  credit  in  a  given  year.  Other  constraints  limiting  the  emergence  of  a  more 
developed rural finance system include the weak link between land and credit markets, interest 
rate controls, subsidized credit, favored treatment of SOEs, and prohibition on foreign banks to 
enter the land-mortgage market. 
 
21. 
Even though land can be used as collateral in accessing bank credit, in practice this is 
not  yet  resulting  in  expanded  rural  credit.  Banks  limit  the  collateral  to  the  amount  of  land  rent 
already paid, implying that only insignificant amounts can be borrowed against the collateral. If 
the borrower cannot repay the debt, banks find themselves in a very difficult position to auction 
the  land. This  situation greatly  limits  the link  between  credit  and land markets  and  retards  the 
expansion of rural credit. 
 
22. 
Control  of  interest  rates  on  loans  and  deposits  prevents  the  financial  system  from 
functioning  effectively.  When  interest  rates  on  deposits  are  limited,  banking  institutions  find  it 
difficult to mobilize savings. The liberalization of interest rates from June 2002 and the resultant 
increase  in  VBARD  interest  rates  will  improve  VBARD’s  financial  performance,  and  raise 
income and profitability.  
 
23. 
The practice of subsidizing credit to the poor may inhibit the development of commercial 
banking and the emergence of durable financial institutions in remote areas. Subsidized credit is 
widely practiced by VBP, NGOs, mass organizations, and to some extent by VBARD in some of 
its  programs.  Experience  with  microfinance  for  the  poor  from  Bangladesh  and  other  countries 
suggest that a sustainable system could be developed using market interest rates. The dramatic 
increase in PCF’s lending program is probably the best evidence for the argument that there is

Favored  treatment  for  SOEs  in  rural  credit  does  not  bode  well  for  expanding  credit  to

Support  given  to  loss-incurring  SOEs  results in  unfair  competition  between  private  enterprises

25. 
Agricultural growth in Viet Nam over the past 15 years was the result of a combination of 
(i) institutional factors such as new incentive to farmers recognized by doi moi as autonomous 
economic  agents;  (ii)  physical  factors  such  as  land,  labor,  and  capital  (mostly  in  the  form  of 
irrigation  system);  and  (iii)  intermediate  inputs  such  as  fertilizers  and  pesticides.  The  role  of 
science and technology in explaining growth over the past 15 years has been relatively small, 
since most of the growth could be explained by increasing factors of production. This strategy is 
unlikely to sustain similar growth in the future for three reasons: (i) the labor force in agriculture 
is starting to decline and with very little land available per farmer, the attractiveness of farming 
will decline further; (ii) new investment in irrigation exhibits decreasing marginal returns as the 
stock  of  irrigation  capital  is  already  very  high  and  requires  increased  repair  and  maintenance 
rather  than  new  expansion,  (iii)  Viet  Nam  has  already  captured  a  large  share  of  world  rice 
markets  so  that  both  domestic  and  international  demand  for  rice  will  start  to  grow  at  a  much 
lower rate than in the past.  
 
26. 
Future  sustained  growth  in  agriculture  will  have  to  come  from  an  increasing  demand 
(both in the country and internationally) for high-value agricultural products. That implies a more 
diversified  agricultural  system,  where  a  variety  of  high-quality  products  are  produced  for  the 
market. This will also imply a change from a perspective that is focused on production volume to 
increasing  production  values.  Future  agricultural  growth  will  also  require  a  policy  environment 
that promotes competition and uses science and technology applied to agricultural production to 
meet  the  demand  of  a  more  sophisticated  market.  Policy  reforms  are  required  to  address  the 
weaknesses  in  agricultural  research,  agricultural  extension,  and  rural  finance.  Competition  will 
be necessary to lower production cost and thus capture higher market shares and profits in the 
international  markets.  Science  and  technology  will  be  necessary  to  identify  new  production 
processes and innovative products that can increase productivity in the agricultural system to a 
much  larger  extent  than  addition  of  labor,  irrigated  land,  and  fertilizers.  Developing  agro-
industry, promoting private small- and medium-sized agro-industry enterprises, and supporting 
market  infrastructure  and  institutions  will  be  necessary  to  capture  higher  value-added  from 
agricultural production. If all these requirements can be fulfilled, Viet Nam will be able to achieve 
a broad-based, market-oriented, and sustainable growth in agriculture in the next decade.
